revision.text: ==English== ===Etymology=== {{suffix|en|Xena|verse}} ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # {{lb|en|fandom slang}} The [[fictional]] [[universe]] depicted in the ''{{w|Xena: Warrior Princess}}'' series. #* '''1998''', Greg Cox, ''Battle On!: An Unauthorized, Irreverent Look at Xena: Warrior Princess'', [https://books.google.ca/books?id=6CZ33h6L8LAC&q=%22xenaverse%22 page 88]: #*: Guess things are different in the '''Xenaverse'''. Maybe Ares and the other gods don't like competition? #* '''2005''', "Doris", quoted in Sue Austin, ''Women's Aggressive Fantasies: A Post-Jungian Exploration of Self-hatred, Love and Agency'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=GJnS9dWas6YC&pg=PA222&dq=%22women+in+the+xenaverse%22 page 22]: #*: The show is an amazing foray into women's expressions of rage â€” there's a lot of other women in the '''Xenaverse''' with a penchant for feats of arms {{...}} #* '''2013''', Jennifer Sky, "[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/10/opinion/my-life-as-a-warrior-princess.html?hp&_r=0 My Life as a Warrior Princess]", ''The New York Times'', 9 September 2013: #*: Gender was not relevant in the '''Xenaverse'''. There, a girl or a boy could be a warlord or a farmer, a bard or a sad sack needing protection. #* {{seemoreCites|en}} # {{lb|en|fandom slang}} The [[fandom]] of ''[[w:Xena: Warrior Princess|Xena: Warrior Princess]]''. #* '''2002''', Jo Marriott & Carly Bramwell, "Maid Marion, Meet Xena", in ''How Xena Changed Our Lives: True Stories by Fans for Fans'' (ed. Nikki Stafford), [https://books.google.com/books?id=5VWV7xmyV3IC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22part+of+the+xenaverse%22 page 72]: #*: Many wonderful people and events have come into our lives from being part of the '''Xenaverse'''. #* '''2003''', Sara Gwellian-Jones, "Histories, Fictions and ''Xena: Warrior Princess''", in ''The Audience Studies Reader'' (eds. Will Brooker & Deborah Jermyn), [https://books.google.com/books?id=MzlGK4BRGTUC&pg=PA187&dq=%22online+xenaverse+is%22 page 188]: #*: The task of mapping the online '''Xenaverse''' is, of course, an impossible one. The '''Xenaverse''' is too expansive, too unstructured, too fluid and fast moving to be charted; {{...}} #* '''2005''', Anik LaChev, "Fan Fiction: A Genre And Its (Final?) Frontiers", ''Spectator'', Volume 25, Number 1, Spring 2005, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0bAqAQAAIAAJ&q=%22xenaverse%22&dq=%22xenaverse%22 page 91]: #*: For instance, when I lived in Italy a couple of years ago, I stumbled across the Italian '''Xenaverse'''. #* {{seemoreCites|en}} ====See also==== * {{l|en|Hercverse}} [[Category:English 3-syllable words]] [[Category:English eponyms]] [[Category:en:Fandom]] [[Category:en:Fictional universes]] [[Category:en:Xena: Warrior Princess]]
